newsitem.title: ROMANIA: KOREA'S DAEWOO IS TOP ROMANIA INVESTOR.
newsitem.headline: KOREA'S DAEWOO IS TOP ROMANIA INVESTOR.

text.p: South Korea's Daewoo Heavy Industries Ltd is the largest single investor in Romania with $209.1 million pumped in since the country opened up to foreign investment after the 1989 fall of communism.

"The South Korean company places first thanks to its contributions to share capital in two joint ventures with Romania," said an official with the Romanian Development Agency (ARD), the country's main foreign investment promoter.
Last year, Daewoo bought 51 percent in a local carmaker, with plans to develop it further a $1.0 billion investment by the year 2000.
In May Daewoo added shipbuilding to its Romanian presence, acquiring a majority stake in a Black Sea shipyard.
According to ARD data, second on the investors list is Italy's New Holland, which bought 51 percent of farm machinery maker Semanatoarea SA for $50.1 million.
Royal Dutch Shell is third with $44 million in a joint oil venture.
Total foreign investment so far amounts to some $2.0 billion, a level which remains low in comparison with other ex-communist Central and East European countries.
Local economists blame the low foreign investment level on slow pace of privatisation and restructuring, red tape and inadequate company laws.

But government sources are more optimistic, saying foreign capital might start flowing in with completion of a mass selloff involving cash sales to local and foreign investors of up to 40 percent of around 4,000 state companies. -- Luli Popescu, Bucharest Newsroom 40-1 3120264
